comment_text: Gosh! It's becoming a common routine!

Still feels like a touchdown when they land, but the announcers are seeming less enthusiastic than before--these flights really are getting that "routine" feel, in spite of being possibly the most cutting-edge orbital rocket in service right now.  Says a lot about SpaceX's performance record, we'll done!
SpaceX is the best rocket maker ever
Grow a tree on terraformed mars!
SpaceX starships should be retired to Orbit and all linked together into a giant space station

Is the "I love You" drone ship totally remote control?  (i.e. no bomb proof rooms in it for workers)  What happens after a landing.  Do support boats with actual people on board sail over to the drone ship, and secure the lander?  Or does the lander just sit on the drone ship until it gets back to land.   If they don't strap it down, is there a chance it could tip over in rough seas on the way back to land?
It was weirding me out every time he mentioned the docking station's name "Of Course I Still Love You", I realized it must be the name after awhile ;but it seemed so random. lol
somthing about nasa high alt recon jet , just made flight plan to fly over the starship test

I love the fact that space launches are getting less fanfare because they are so routine now. I still like seeing the fanfare during firsts, like crew dragon just a while back, but they have been launching something like once a week lately it seems, so it is good to see if becoming something that looks easy for them.

Think of explosions as rapid oxidization. It becomes an explosion when materials create more oxygen then they need for their own reaction. I remember from redux calculation in chemistry that TNT produces about 16 times the oxygen needed. In general, you need a flame of levels of compression to start the reaction.
The point is parking massive amounts of rocket fuel next to a habitat on Mars, is a lot safer than the same situation on earth. An atmosphere without oxygen is not without advantages :)

Personally, I liked not having a 10-second countdown.  I have no issue with saying "10 seconds" or perhaps even "5 seconds", but the 10-9-8-7... seems old-fashioned after 6 decades of televised launches, though perhaps it makes it more fun for kids as it may help teach them to count backwards ;).  I'd rather they just show the timer on the screen and report milestone events on the nets.
